conclusion: To determine the time during which there is an induced current in the frame, we need to analyze the motion of the frame through the magnetic field.

Identify the relevant parameters: Side length of the square conductor frame: \( l \), Width of the magnetic field: \( d \), Speed of the frame: \( v \), Time taken for the frame to move completely through the magnetic field: \( t \).

premise: The frame moves uniformly and its speed is \( v \).
conclusion: The time \( t \) required for the frame to move from one side of the magnetic field to the other (a distance of \( d \)) can be calculated as \( t = \frac{d}{v} \).

An induced current occurs when the magnetic flux through the loop changes. This happens when the frame enters or exits the magnetic field because the magnetic field lines are perpendicular to the plane of the frame.
The frame starts entering the magnetic field at \( x = 0 \). The frame exits the magnetic field at \( x = d \).

premise: The frame will be fully inside the magnetic field when \( 0 \leq x \leq l \).
conclusion: The time taken for the frame to move from \( x = 0 \) to \( x = l \) is \( t_{\text{in}} = \frac{l}{v} \).

premise: The time taken for the frame to move from \( x = l \) to \( x = d \) is \( t_{\text{out}} = \frac{d - l}{v} \).
conclusion: Total time for the frame to be inside the magnetic field is \( t_{\text{total}} = \frac{l}{v} + \frac{d - l}{v} = \frac{d}{v} \).

premise: The time during which there is an induced current in the frame is the same as the time it takes for the frame to move completely through the magnetic field.
conclusion: The time during which there is an induced current in the frame is \( \frac{d}{v} \).
